text: Selected academic work from Purdue University‚Äôs Cybersecurity and Computer & Information Technology programs.

title: Coursework
section: Computational Humor: Pun Analysis with NLP
text:
Computational Humor: Pun Analysis with NLP
Graduate NLP Coursework






Tipüß† Full pun comprehension pipeline ‚Äî identification, disambiguation, explanation, and scoring



Tackled the SemEval 2017 shared task on phonetic puns: given a sentence containing a pun, automatically find the intended word, explain why it‚Äôs funny, and score how good the joke is.


Humor is one of the hardest problems in NLP ‚Äî puns in particular require simultaneously reasoning about phonetics, semantics, and context. This project built a five-stage pipeline to decompose the problem: find phonetically similar word pairs, pick the right sense of each, generate a natural language explanation, and output a composite quality score.
The design decisions were as deliberate as the implementation. BERT-based masked prediction was evaluated and rejected for word sense disambiguation in favor of Lesk similarity ‚Äî not due to capability but due to the near-total absence of pun-annotated training data. GPT-3 was chosen specifically for the language generation stage where discrete methods fundamentally break down: composing fluent, coherent explanations of jokes is a generation problem, not a retrieval one.








üìä Dataset
SemEval 2017 phonetic pun corpus


üîß Pipeline
5 stages ‚Äî identification ‚Üí sound similarity ‚Üí disambiguation ‚Üí explanation ‚Üí scoring


ü§ñ Generation
GPT-3 for natural language joke explanation


üìê Scoring
Pronunciation distance (IPA edit) + cosine distance of vectorized definitions


üîä Phonetics
ARPABET ‚Üí IPA transcription pipeline via SoundsLike




Stack:

GPT-3 NLTK SoundsLike Lesk Similarity PyDictionary


NLP Word Sense Disambiguation IPA / ARPABET Cosine Similarity SemEval 2017

title: Coursework
text:
Enterprise Network Design & Administration
CNIT 34200 ‚Äî Undergraduate Networking Capstone






NoteüèóÔ∏è Full-stack enterprise network built from scratch in vSphere



Four isolated network zones, an Active Directory forest spanning two sites, a custom BIND DNS resolver, and DFS replication ‚Äî all provisioned and wired together end-to-end.


Most networking coursework stops at configuration. This capstone started at the hypervisor. Every VM, NIC assignment, port group, and IP was provisioned from scratch in a shared vSphere/vCenter environment ‚Äî meaning mistakes had real consequences, including accidentally routing traffic through another group‚Äôs switch port.
The architecture mirrored a real enterprise: a pfSense firewall segmenting WAN, HQ LAN, DMZ, and a remote office subnet; Windows Server 2019 DCs at both sites forming an AD forest; a CentOS BIND server in the DMZ replacing the upstream Purdue resolver with an internally-controlled one; and DFS namespace + replication tying HQ and Remote together for distributed file access. The three-part WAN debugging incident ‚Äî a misassigned NIC, stale gateway entries, and a misconfigured server gateway all compounding simultaneously ‚Äî was the most technically dense troubleshooting exercise of the program.








üåê Network zones
4 ‚Äî WAN, HQ LAN, DMZ, Remote office


üñ•Ô∏è VMs provisioned
pfSense, CentOS BIND, 2√ó Windows Server, 2√ó Windows client


üóÇÔ∏è Services deployed
Active Directory, DFS namespace + replication, BIND DNS, NAT


üêõ Debugging
3-part WAN failure ‚Äî misassigned NIC, conflicting gateways, wrong server default GW


üîí Security policy
NAT outbound rules configured to block DMZ egress by design




Stack:

pfSense VMware vSphere Active Directory BIND DFS


Windows Server 2019 CentOS NAT / Firewall Rules AD Sites & Services DNS Forwarding

title: Coursework
section: Intrusion Detection System Deployment & Penetration Testing
text:
Intrusion Detection System Deployment & Penetration Testing
CNIT 45500 ‚Äî Network Security






Important‚öîÔ∏è End-to-end attack-and-detect lab ‚Äî from packet capture to SOC dashboard



Two NIDS engines, two vulnerable targets, one attacker VM, and a live validated attack pipeline. Every component provisioned, configured, and verified from scratch.


The goal wasn‚Äôt just to install Snort ‚Äî it was to build the full operational context around it. That meant standing up a realistic target environment (Metasploitable and Ultimate LAMP), provisioning an attacker machine (Kali), and wiring two Security Onion instances together as a distributed detection stack, all on a pfSense-segmented lab network in vSphere.
Snort ran as the capture sensor using PF_RING for high-throughput packet ingestion, Emerging Threats Open signatures, and Zeek for protocol analysis and file extraction. Suricata sat downstream as the event correlator and SOC-facing dashboard. The pipeline was validated end-to-end: a slow loris HTTP flood and an nmap port scan launched from Kali hit the Ultimate LAMP machine, were captured by Snort, forwarded via Filebeat, and surfaced as alerts in Suricata‚Äôs management UI. A production-realistic configuration detail ‚Äî Snort‚Äôs PulledPork signature updater was blocked by the WAN firewall at startup ‚Äî required diagnosing and temporarily opening egress for the rule download before hardening back down.








üñ•Ô∏è VMs deployed
4 ‚Äî Kali (attacker), Metasploitable, Ultimate LAMP, 2√ó Security Onion


üîç NIDS engines
Snort (sensor) + Suricata (correlator) running in parallel


‚ö° Attacks validated
Slow loris HTTP flood + nmap port scan, end-to-end through the pipeline


üì¶ Log pipeline
Snort ‚Üí Filebeat ‚Üí Suricata ‚Üí Elasticsearch ‚Üí SOC dashboard


üåê Ruleset
Emerging Threats Open via PulledPork, tuned to RFC-1918 HOME_NET




Stack:

Snort Suricata Security Onion Zeek Filebeat Elasticsearch


Kali Linux pfSense PF_RING PulledPork VMware vSphere

title: Coursework
text:
Vulnerability Assessment & Remediation
CNIT 47100 ‚Äî Ethical Hacking & Network Defense






Warningüî¥ 7 critical vulnerabilities found ‚Äî 2 exploited, 1 remediated and re-verified



Full assessment lifecycle against Metasploitable 2 & 3: discovery, exploitation, fix, and a follow-up scan to prove it.


Vulnerability scanning is easy. Understanding what the findings actually mean ‚Äî and proving you can both exploit and fix them ‚Äî is the real exercise. This lab ran the complete assessment lifecycle: automated scanning with Nessus and nmap-vulners to build a findings inventory, manual exploitation of two critical vulnerabilities to demonstrate real impact, remediation of one, and a follow-up Nessus scan to verify the fix was effective and not just assumed.
The two exploits chosen were deliberately different in character. The VNC takeover was trivially simple ‚Äî the password was literally password ‚Äî but demonstrated full graphical remote control of the machine, making the business risk viscerally obvious. The ProFTPD mod_copy exploit was more surgical: anonymous FTP access combined with SITE CPFR/SITE CPTO to silently copy /etc/passwd to a web-accessible path without authentication. No credentials, no noise, one command.








üî¥ Critical vulns found
7 via Nessus ‚Äî bind shell backdoor, weak RNG in OpenSSH/OpenSSL, NFS disclosure, VNC


üìã CVEs catalogued
20 application/version pairs across ProFTPD, OpenSSH, ISC Bind via nmap-vulners


üí• Exploits demonstrated
2 ‚Äî VNC remote takeover (Metasploitable 2), ProFTPD passwd exfil (Metasploitable 3)


‚úÖ Remediation verified
VNC password hardened via vncpasswd, clean re-scan confirmed


üõ°Ô∏è WAF detection
wafw00f identified ModSecurity on certifiedhacker.com; no WAF on either target




Stack:

Nessus nmap wafw00f VNC ProFTPD


CVE Analysis Vulnerability Remediation Network Scanning WAF Detection Exploit Development

title: Pranav Bhusari
text:
Hey, I‚Äôm Pranav! I most recently worked as an AI/ML vulnerability researcher at Cromulence, building and fine-tuning LLMs for code generation and document translation in air-gapped environments.
Outside of work, I‚Äôve been building STEM Network ‚Äî a city-scale IoT sensor network for monitoring urban street trees that won 1st place globally at Microsoft‚Äôs Azure IoT hackathon and landed real deployment funding from the City of Boulder.
I‚Äôm into the full stack of ML: from data curation pipelines and LoRA fine-tuning all the way down to embedded systems and LoRaWAN gateways.
Get in touch View experience

title: Projects
text:
May 2021 ‚Äì Summer 2024 ¬∑ DevPost






NoteüèÜ 1st Place ‚Äî Microsoft Azure IoT Hack for Sustainability (Global)



Built a deployment-ready demo in 48 hours. Endorsed by San Jos√© city arborists and backed by peer-reviewed urban forestry research.





STEM Network live dashboard showing soil moisture readings across monitored trees


Urban forests are critical infrastructure ‚Äî but newly-planted street trees have up to 30% annual mortality, largely from inadequate watering during the first few years of establishment. STEM is a city-scale IoT sensor network that gives urban foresters real-time soil moisture visibility across every monitored tree, turning reactive tree care into data-driven stewardship.
What started as a hackathon project became a real deployment. After winning globally, I took STEM from prototype to a working local network ‚Äî securing Microsoft for Startups backing and $10,000 from the City of Boulder, Colorado to fund the first sensor rollout. I continued developing the system as a Purdue directed project, spending the summer of 2024 on the hardware side: designing and building out a LoRaWAN gateway and conducting a rigorous embedded system power study to validate the 5-year battery life target for field-deployed sensor nodes.
Each node is a capacitive moisture sensor paired with an ESP32 microcontroller, potted in vandalism-resistant PVC housing for underground installation. Readings stream over MQTT ‚Üí LoRaWAN gateway ‚Üí Azure IoT Hub ‚Üí Stream Analytics ‚Üí SQL Server, surfaced through an ASP.NET Core dashboard with Azure Maps and Charts.js for geospatial and historical views.








üöÄ Deployment
Taken to a live local network ‚Äî from 48-hour demo to real-world rollout


üí∞ Funding
$110,000 total ‚Äî $100K Microsoft for Startups credits + $10K City of Boulder


üåç Hackathon
1st place globally, Microsoft Azure IoT Hack for Sustainability


üì° Hardware
Built LoRaWAN gateway + embedded power study (Summer 2024)


üéì Academic
Continued as a Purdue directed project through graduation


üå≤ Problem
30% annual urban tree mortality ‚Äî solved through continuous soil monitoring




Stack:

C# .NET / ASP.NET Core Python ESP32


Azure IoT Hub Azure Stream Analytics Azure Blob Storage Azure SQL Server Azure Maps Microsoft for Startups


LoRaWAN MQTT Embedded Systems Power Analysis Bootstrap Charts.js

title: Experience
text:
Cybersecurity Research Engineering Co-op
Peraton Labs | Jan 2023 ‚Äì Dec 2023

Contributed to the design, programming, and implementation of a novel, bespoke high-speed Network Intrusion Detection System (NIDS) using C, Bash, ELK Stack, Kibana, and Elasticsearch, enabling microsecond-level packet-timing fingerprinting
Created a mock network attack in CORE exploiting RIPv2 and IPsec routing protocols, and demonstrated a following mitigation by implementing hash table caching in C for the NIDS


C Bash ELK Stack Kibana Elasticsearch

Designed backend architecture leveraging Docker, ElasticSearch, and PostgreSQL to fit scalability and performance standards
